TF020250-FRENCH CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF033086-TUNISIA - PRIVATE INVESTMENT
            CREDIT PROJECT,TF033085-TUNISIA - PRIVATE INVESTMENT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Private Investment Credit
            Project's overall outcome is rated as satisfactory. The
            lessons learned from the project include: a) Financial
            intermediation lending is an important instrument for
            following up structural adjustment operations. The project
            demonstrates that a well-designed and monitored financial
            intermediation loan can play a role in reinforcing the
            introduction of financial sector reforms, monitoring their
            application, and providing a framework for discussing
            further modifications in financial sector reforms. b) Beyond
            the minimum capital standards established by prudential
            regulations, some reasonable measure of portfolio quality
            ought to be used as a criterion for access to an IBRD line
            of credit. c) The need to develop a long-term strategy for
            the future of the development banks was expressed as a
            covenant in the Guarantee Agreements for the three direct
            lines of credit to development banks, thus placing the
            responsibility for these strategies on the Government, in
            its role as Guarantor. d) A single apex loan that would
            finance eligible subprojects of participating financial
            intermediaries on a first come, first served basis would
            have been a more efficient, as well as equitable, instrument
            for channeling IBRD funds to finance private investments. e)
            The complexity of this project made it quite difficult to
            administer on behalf of a co-financier.
